deterministic-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, detected on 1st day
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the disease is detected the day the unit first shows clinical signs and the authorities can immediately destroy the unit.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 the unit will be Latent. - On day 2 the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 3 the unit will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 4.

variable-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, detected on 1st day, check reporting variables
variable-test.description: Test that the number of units detected, the cumulative number of units detected, and the day of the first detection is reported correctly. In this scenario, the same as "detected on 1st day" above, the disease is detected the day the unit first shows clinical signs and the authorities can immediately destroy the unit.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description: The parameters are identical to the test "detected on 1st day" above. The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day. The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. There is no spread or vaccination. What should happen: - On day 1 the unit will be Latent. - On day 2 the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. Note that the "firstDetection" output should have no numeric value until this day. - On day 3 the unit will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, never detected (p fixed low)
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the disease is not detected because the probability of detection vs. days clinical is fixed below 0.5.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day.
The probability of detection is 0.2 when the unit has been showing clinical signs for 1 day. It increases linearly to 0.4 by the third day the unit has been showing clinical signs. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 the unit will be Latent. - On days 2-6 (5 days) the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected because with "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, the probability of detection will always be too low. - On day 7 the unit will be immune.

variable-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, never detected (p fixed low), check reporting variables
variable-test.description: Test that the number of units detected, the cumulative number of units detected, and the day of the first detection is reported correctly. In this scenario, the same as "detection of clinical signs, never detected (p fixed low)" above, the disease is not detected because the probability of detection vs. days clinical is fixed below 0.5.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to the test "detection of clinical signs, never detected (p fixed low)" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 the unit will be Latent. - On days 2-6 (5 days) the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected because with "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, the probability of detection will always be too low. The "firstDetection" output should have no numeric value. - On day 7 the unit will be immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, detected on 2nd day (p too low until day 2)
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the disease is not detected until the second day the unit is showing clinical signs.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day.
The probability of detection is 0.4 when the unit first shows clinical signs. It increases linearly to 0.6 after one day. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 the unit will be Latent. - On day 2 the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected because with "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, the probability of detection is too low (0.4). - On day 3 the probability of detection will be 0.6. The unit will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 4 the unit will be destroyed. Its state will show as Destroyed on day 5.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, detected on 3rd day (p too low until day 3)
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the disease is not detected until the third day the unit is showing clinical signs.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day.
The probability of detection is 0.4 for the first 2 days that the unit is showing clinical signs. It increases linearly to 0.6 on the third day. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 the unit will be Latent. - On days 2 and 3 the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected because with "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, the probability of detection is too low (0.4). - On day 4 the probability of detection will be 0.6. The unit will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 5 the unit will be destroyed. Its state will show as Destroyed on day 6.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, detected on 3rd day, override initial state
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the unit starts as infectious clinical, and disease is detected on third day the unit is showing clinical signs.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day.
The probability of detection is 0.4 for the first 2 days that the unit is showing clinical signs. It increases linearly to 0.6 on the third day. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On days 1 and 2 the unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected because with "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, the probability of detection is too low (0.4). - On day 3 the probability of detection will be 0.6. The unit will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 4 the unit will be destroyed. Its state will show as Destroyed on day 5.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection of clinical signs, detected on 3rd day, override initial state + days left in state
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario where the unit starts as infectious clinical with 2 days left in the 5-day infectious clinical state. Disease is detected on third day a unit is showing clinical signs, so the unit will be detected on the first day of the simulation.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 1 day.
The probability of detection is 0.4 for the first 2 days that the unit is showing clinical signs. It increases linearly to 0.6 on the third day. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 the unit will be Infectious Clinical, starting out on the 4th day of its clinical period. The unit will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 2 the unit will be destroyed. Its state will show as Destroyed on day 3.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection vs. public awareness 0
deterministic-test.description: Test that the probability of detection can be influenced by days since the 1st detection. In this baseline scenario, the probability of detection vs. days since the 1st detection is constant.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 5 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
For both cattle and pigs, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 0.55.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 both units will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 (cattle) will be Infectious Clinical. The probability of detection = the baseline before the 1st detection (0.55) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (1.0) = 0.55. Unit 0 will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. - On day 3 unit 0 will be destroyed. Unit 1 (pigs) will be Infectious Clinical. The probability of detection = the value for 1 day since the 1st detection (0.55) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (1.0) = 0.55. Unit 1 will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 4 unit 1 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection vs. public awareness, p too low for unit 1
deterministic-test.description: Test that the probability of detection can be influenced by days since the 1st detection. In this scenario, the probability of detection vs. days since the 1st detection is constant. The probability of detection vs. days showing clinical signs is also constant; it is high enough for detection for unit 0 but too low for detection for unit 1.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 5 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
For cattle, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. For pigs, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 0.6. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak (for both production types) is fixed at 0.55.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 both units will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 (cattle) will be Infectious Clinical. The probability of detection = the baseline before the 1st detection (0.55) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (1.0) = 0.55. Unit 0 will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. - On day 3 unit 0 will be destroyed. Unit 1 (pigs) will be Infectious Clinical. The probability of detection = the value for 1 day since the 1st detection (0.55) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (0.6) = 0.33. With "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, this is too low for detection. Unit 1 will not be detected. - On days 4-7 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical, but the probability of detection will always be too low. - On day 8 unit 1 will be immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: detection vs. public awareness, p high enough for unit 1 1 day after 1st detection
deterministic-test.description: Test that the probability of detection can be influenced by days since the 1st detection. In this two-unit scenario, the probability of detection vs. days since the 1st detection starts low and increases 1 day after the first detection. The probability of detection vs. days showing clinical signs is constant for both production types. For unit 0, this probability is high enough to trigger a detection with the baseline (pre-1st detection) probability. For unit 1, the probability of detection vs. days showing clinical signs is low enough that it requires the increase in public awareness to push the combined probability over the threshold for detection.

For pigs, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 0.6. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak (for both production types) is 0.55 on "day 0" (the baseline before the 1st detection) and 1.0 on day 1 (the day after the 1st detection) and later.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.

The probability of detection = the value for 1 day since the 1st detection (1.0) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (0.6) = 0.6. With "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, unit 1 will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 4 unit 1 will be destroyed.

For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 0.6. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak (for both production types) is 0.55 on "day 0" (the baseline before the 1st detection), day 1 (the day after the 1st detection), and day 2, then is 1.0 on day 3 and later.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 both units will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 (cattle) will be Infectious Clinical. With "fixed" random numbers of 0.5, this is too low for detection. Unit 1 will not be detected. - On day 4 the probability of detection for unit 1 (pigs) = the value for 2 days since the 1st detection (0.55) times the value for day 2 of the clinical period (0.6) = 0.33. deterministic-test.short-name: detection vs. public awareness, subclinical period shorter
deterministic-test.description: Test that the probability of detection can be influenced by days since the 1st detection. This scenario is identical to "detection vs. public awareness, p high enough for unit 1 2 days after 1st detection" above, except the subclinical period for unit 1 is 1 day shorter. The outcome of the scenario should be the same as for the earlier test, because it is the number of days since the 1st detection, not the number of days into the clinical period, that should determine when unit 1 is detected.

deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle (unit 0), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 5 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs (unit 1), the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 2 days, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 5 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
For cattle, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. For pigs, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 0.6. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak (for both production types) is 0.55 on "day 0" (the baseline before the 1st detection) and day 1 (the day after the 1st detection), then is 1.0 on day 2 and later.

The probability of detection = the baseline before the 1st detection (0.55) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (1.0) = 0.55. Unit 0 will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. - On day 3 unit 0 will be destroyed. Unit 1 will still be Infectious Subclinical. - On day 4 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. The probability of detection for unit 1 = the value for 2 days since the 1st detection (1.0) times the value for day 1 of the clinical period (0.6) = 0.6. variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 1a, check detection reasons
variable-test.description: Check that the reason for detection is reported correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 4 days, and immunity lasts 4 days.
The movement rate from pig units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment each day. There is no movement in the other direction. Latent units cannot be the source of an infection.
For unit 1 (a pig unit), the probability of detection is 0 on the first and second days showing clinical signs, and 1 on following days. In this set of scenarios, this parameter is used to control when trace is initiated.
For unit 0 (a cattle unit), the probability of detection is 1/3, which is always too low for detection when using fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. This parameter is set this way so that any detection we see will be the result of an exam as part of the trace investigation, not from "regular" detection.
When a unit is detected, trace out will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is a 2-day delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined, visually inspected (like regular detection, but with 2x the probability of detection) and tested for disease. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. It will be slated for destruction and a trace out will be initiated. - On day 5 unit 1 will be destroyed (its state will show as destroyed on day 6). - On day 6 unit 0 will be found by tracing (2 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts, with its increased probability of detection, will show that unit 0 is diseased. Unit 0 will be slated for destruction. - On day 7 unit 0 will be destroyed. Its state will show as destroyed on day 8.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 2, check detection reasons
variable-test.description: Check that the reason for detection is reported correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 4 days, and immunity lasts 4 days.
The movement rate from pig units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment each day. There is no movement in the other direction. Latent units cannot be the source of an infection.
For unit 1 (a pig unit), the probability of detection is 0 on the first and second days showing clinical signs, and 1 on following days. In this set of scenarios, this parameter is used to control when trace is initiated.
For unit 0 (a cattle unit), the probability of detection is 1/3, which is always too low for detection when using fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. This parameter is set this way so that any detection we see will be the result of an exam as part of the trace investigation, not from "regular" detection.
When a unit is detected, trace out will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is a 2-day delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined, visually inspected (like regular detection, but with 2x the probability of detection) and tested for disease. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. It will be slated for destruction and a trace out will be initiated. - On day 5 unit 1 will be destroyed (its state will show as destroyed on day 6). - On day 8 unit 0 will be Naturally Immune. Unit 0 will be found by tracing (4 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts has a high enough probability to detect signs of disease, but because the unit has recovered, there will be no signs. Samples will be taken for testing. - On day 10 the test results will be available and will show that unit 0 still had antibodies at the time the test samples were taken. Unit 0 will be slated for destruction. - On day 11 unit 0 will be destroyed. Its state will show as destroyed on day 12.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 1a, check first detection
variable-test.description: Check that the first detection (overall, and for each production type and by each means of detection) is reported correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "trace RFC example 1a, check detection reasons" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. That is the overall first detection, the first detection of pigs, and the first detection by clinical signs. - On day 6 unit 0 will be found by tracing (2 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts, with its increased probability of detection, will show that unit 0 is diseased. That is the first detection of cattle.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 2, check first detection
variable-test.description: Check that the first detection (overall, and for each production type and by each means of detection) is reported correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "trace RFC example 2, check detection reasons" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. That is the overall first detection, the first detection of pigs, and the first detection by clinical signs. - On day 8 unit 0 will be Naturally Immune. Unit 0 will be found by tracing (4 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts has a high enough probability to detect signs of disease, but because the unit has recovered, there will be no signs. Samples will be taken for testing. - On day 10 the test results will be available and will show that unit 0 still had antibodies at the time the test samples were taken. That is the first detection of cattle, and the first detection by a test.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 1a, check exam counts
variable-test.description: Check that the examinations done and the reasons for the exams are counted correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "trace RFC example 1a, check detection reasons" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. It will be slated for destruction and a trace out will be initiated. - On day 5 unit 1 will be destroyed (its state will show as destroyed on day 6). - On day 6 unit 0 will be found by tracing (2 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts, with its increased probability of detection, will show that unit 0 is diseased. We should count 1 cattle unit/25 animals examined, done because a direct contact was traced forward (DirFwd). Unit 0 will be slated for destruction. - On day 7 unit 0 will be destroyed. Its state will show as destroyed on day 8.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 2, check exam counts
variable-test.description: Check that the examinations done and the reasons for the exams are counted correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "trace RFC example 2, check detection reasons" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. That is the overall first detection, the first detection of pigs, and the first detection by clinical signs. - On day 8 unit 0 will be Naturally Immune. Unit 0 will be found by tracing (4 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts has a high enough probability to detect signs of disease, but because the unit has recovered, there will be no signs. Even though no signs were found, the exam is still counted; we count 1 cattle unit/25 animals examined, done because a direct contact was traced forward (DirFwd). Samples will be taken for testing. - On day 10 the test results will be available and will show that unit 0 still had antibodies at the time the test samples were taken. That is the first detection of cattle, and the first detection by a test.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 7, check exam counts
variable-test.description: Check that the examinations done and the reasons for the exams are counted correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For unit 2 (the unit that ships), the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 4 days, and immunity lasts 4 days. For unit 1 (the unit that receives the shipment), the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 4 days, and immunity lasts 4 days. For unit 0 (the unit that causes the destruction ring later in the scenario), the latent period lasts 2 days, the infectious clinical period lasts 4 days, and immunity lasts 4 days.
The movement rate from pig units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment each day. There is no movement in the other direction. Latent units cannot be the source of an infection.
For unit 2 (a pig unit), the probability of detection is 0 on the first day showing clinical signs, and 1 on following days. In this set of scenarios, this parameter is used to control when trace is initiated.
For unit 1 (a cattle unit), the probability of detection is 1/3, which is always too low for detection when using fixed "random" numbers of 0.5. This parameter is set this way so that any detection we see will be the result of an exam as part of the trace investigation, not from "regular" detection.
There is no detection of sheep units.
When a unit is detected, trace out will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is a 2-day delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined, visually inspected (like regular detection, but with 2x the probability of detection) and tested for disease. Test results take 3 days. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 1. - On day 3 units 0 and 2 will be detected. They will be slated for destruction and a trace out will be initiated. Unit 1 will also be slated for destruction because it is within 12 km of unit 0. - On day 4 units 0, 1 and 2 will be destroyed (their state will show as destroyed on day 5). - On day 5 unit 1 will be found by tracing (2 days after the trace was initiated). However, the unit is already destroyed, so there is no possibility of detecting signs that it was once diseased, or of doing further traces. No exam will be counted.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 1a, check test counts
variable-test.description: Check that the diagnostic tests done and the reasons for the tests are counted correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "trace RFC example 1a, check detection reasons" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. It will be slated for destruction and a trace out will be initiated. - On day 5 unit 1 will be destroyed (its state will show as destroyed on day 6). - On day 6 unit 0 will be found by tracing (2 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts, with its increased probability of detection, will show that unit 0 is diseased. Because a visual exam was sufficient to detect disease, no test will be ordered. Unit 0 will be slated for destruction. - On day 7 unit 0 will be destroyed. Its state will show as destroyed on day 8.

variable-test.short-name: trace RFC example 2, check test counts
variable-test.description: Check that the diagnostic tests done and the reasons for the tests are counted correctly. This scenario is copied from the one of the same name under "control measures" tests.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "trace RFC example 2, check detection reasons" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will not be detected, because the base probability of detection is too low. However, unit 1 will be detected on this day. That is the overall first detection, the first detection of pigs, and the first detection by clinical signs. - On day 8 unit 0 will be Naturally Immune. Unit 0 will be found by tracing (4 days after the trace was initiated). A visual inspection by experts has a high enough probability to detect signs of disease, but because the unit has recovered, there will be no signs. Samples will be taken for testing. We should count 1 cattle unit/25 animals tested, done because a direct contact was traced forward (DirFwd). - On day 10 the test results will be available and will show that unit 0 still had antibodies at the time the test samples were taken.

deterministic-test.short-name: test sensitivity just < threshold for success, unit Latent
deterministic-test.description: This is one of a group of scenarios to test the sensitivity and specificity parameters for tests. In this scenario, the unit found by trace is latent, but the test sensitivity is too low and the result will be negative.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The movement rate from pig units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment per day. The distance of shipments is fixed at 10 km. The probability of infection given exposure is 1. There is no movement in the other direction.
Only pig units are detected. The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
The authorities do trace out only. The probability of success for a trace-out investigation is 1, and there is no delay for getting trace results. Units found by trace are quarantined and tested. The test sensitivity is 0.495, and the specificity is 1. Units that test positive will be destroyed.
What should happen: - On day 1 the pig unit (unit 1) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will ship to and infect unit 0. - On day 3 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace out from unit 1 will find unit 0. Unit 0 will be Latent, but the test sensitivity is too low to detect it, so unit 0 will not be marked for destruction. - On day 4 unit 1 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 5.

deterministic-test.short-name: test specificity just < threshold for success, unit Vaccine Immune
deterministic-test.description: This is one of a group of scenarios to test the sensitivity and specificity parameters for tests. In this scenario, the unit found by trace is not infected (it is vaccine immune), but the test specificity is too low and the result will be a false positive.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The movement rate from pig units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment per day. The distance of shipments is fixed at 10 km. The probability of infection given exposure is zero. There is no movement in the other direction.

Units found by trace are quarantined and tested. The test sensitivity is 1, and the specificity is 0.495. Units that test positive will be destroyed.
A vaccination program begins at the first detection. Units within 15 km of a detection will be vaccinated. The authorities can vaccinate an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - On day 1 the pig unit (unit 1) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will ship to unit 0 but will not infect it. - On day 3 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace out will be requested from unit 1. Unit 0 will be marked for vaccination because it is within 15 km of unit 1. - On day 4 unit 1 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 5. Unit 0 will be vaccinated. - On day 5 the trace requested on day 3 will find unit 0, which is now Vaccine Immune, but the test specificity is too low, so unit 0 will be marked for destruction. - On day 6 unit 0 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 7.

deterministic-test.short-name: test specificity just > threshold for success, unit Vaccine Immune
deterministic-test.description: This is one of a group of scenarios to test the sensitivity and specificity parameters for tests. In this scenario, the unit found by trace is not infected (it is vaccine immune), and the test specificity is sufficiently high to get a true negative.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The movement rate from pig units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment per day. The distance of shipments is fixed at 10 km. The probability of infection given exposure is zero. There is no movement in the other direction.
Only pig units are detected. The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
The authorities do trace out only. The probability of success for a trace-out investigation is 1, and there is a 2-day delay for getting trace results. Units found by trace are quarantined and tested. The test sensitivity is 1, and the specificity is 0.505. Units that test positive will be destroyed.
A vaccination program begins at the first detection. Units within 15 km of a detection will be vaccinated. The authorities can vaccinate an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - On day 1 the pig unit (unit 1) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will ship to unit 0 but will not infect it. - On day 3 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace out will be requested from unit 1. Unit 0 will be marked for vaccination because it is within 15 km of unit 1. - On day 4 unit 1 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 5. Unit 0 will be vaccinated. - On day 5 the trace requested on day 3 will find unit 0, which is now Vaccine Immune, and the test specificity is high enough to get a true negative, so unit 0 will not be marked for destruction.

deterministic-test.short-name: test, unit Destroyed (baseline)
deterministic-test.description:
This is one of a group of scenarios to test the sensitivity and specificity parameters for tests. In this scenario, the unit found by trace is Destroyed. We want to make sure that no test occurs for a Destroyed unit, which is functionally equivalent to a negative result.
This scenario has 3 units, numbered 0, 1, and 2. 0 ships to 1 and 1 ships to 2. The unit that a test may be attempted on is unit 1, in the middle. We can tell whether a test occurs and comes up positive because a positive test will trigger a further trace out to unit 2.
This scenario is a baseline to establish that trace out will cause unit 2 to be destroyed if unit 1 tests positive.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The rate of direct contacts from sheep units to cattle units is fixed at 1 contact per day. The rate of indirect contacts from cattle units to pig units is fixed at 1 shipment per day. The distance of contacts is fixed at 10 km. The probability of infection given exposure is 1.
Only sheep units are detected. The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy 1 unit each day.
The authorities do trace out only. The probability of success for a trace-out investigation is 1, and there is a 3-day delay for getting trace results. Units found by trace are quarantined and tested. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1. Units that test positive will be destroyed.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will ship to and infect unit 1, which will in turn infect unit 2 on day 4. - On day 3 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace out will be requested from unit 0. - On day 4 unit 0 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 5. - On day 6 the trace requested on day 3 will find unit 1. This is the important day to watch when comparing this scenario to the next one. Unit 1 will be tested, and because it is infectious clinical, the test will be positive. Unit 1 will be marked for destruction and a trace out will be requested. - On day 7 unit 1 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 8. - On day 9 the trace requested on day 6 will find unit 2, which is now Infectious Clinical. Unit 2 will be tested and found to be diseased. Unit 2 will be marked for destruction. - On day 10 unit 2 will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 11.

deterministic-test.short-name: test, unit Destroyed
deterministic-test.description:
This is one of a group of scenarios to test the sensitivity and specificity parameters for tests. In this scenario, the unit found by trace is Destroyed. We want to make sure that no test occurs for a Destroyed unit, which is functionally equivalent to a negative result.
This scenario has 3 units, numbered 0, 1, and 2. 0 ships to 1 and 1 ships to 2. The unit that a test may be attempted on is unit 1, in the middle. We can tell whether a test occurs and comes up positive because a positive test will trigger a further trace out to unit 2.
In this scenario the unit in the middle is Destroyed at the time of the test, so trace out should not continue to unit 2.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness without clinical signs lasts 1 day, infectiousness with clinical signs lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The rate of direct contacts from sheep units to cattle units is fixed at 1 contact per day. The rate of indirect contacts from cattle units to pig units is fixed at 1 shipment per day. The distance of contacts is fixed at 10 km. The probability of infection given exposure is 1.
Only sheep units are detected. The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy 1 unit each day.
The authorities do trace out only, not trace in. The probability of success for a trace-out investigation is 1, and there is a 3-day delay for getting trace results. Units found by trace are quarantined and tested. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1. Units that test positive will be destroyed.
The authorities also do ring destruction. All cattle units within 10 km of a detection will be destroyed. Detected units have priority over units that are in a destruction ring.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will ship to and infect unit 1, which will in turn infect unit 2 on day 4. - On day 3 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace out will be requested from unit 0. Unit 1 will also be marked for destruction because it is a cattle unit within 10 km of a detection. - On day 4 units 0 and 1 are both marked for destruction, but unit 0 has priority, so it will be destroyed. Its state will appear as Destroyed on day 5. - On day 5 unit 1 will be destroyed. - On day 6 the trace requested on day 3 will find unit 1. The policy calls for unit 1 to be tested, but since unit 1 is destroyed, there is no need. No trace out will happen. - On the remaining days the infection in unit 2 will run its course.

variable-test.short-name: test, unit Destroyed, check TP/TN/FP/FN count

variable-test.short-name: trace leads to previously detected unit, no previous detection
variable-test.description: Test that when a trace leads to a unit that has already been detected, an exam is not done. In this baseline scenario, the unit has not already been detected.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Pig units ship to sheep units once per day. Sheep units ship to cattle units once per day. Latent units cannot be the source of an exposure. The probability of infection given exposure is always too low to infect.
The probability of detection for sheep and cattle units is too low for detection by self-reporting, but an exam can detect the unit any time during its clinical period. Pig units will be detected by self-reporting on the second day they show clinical signs. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. No detections will happen. Counts of events: 2 exposures, 0 detections, 0 exposures potentially traced, 0 exposures actually traced, and 0 exams. - On day 2 unit 0 will again ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. Unit 2 will be detected. The trace out will discover todays and yesterdays shipments to unit 0. An exam will detect disease at unit 0 and the trace out will continue to discover todays and yesterdays shipments to unit 1. An exam will not detect disease at unit 1. Counts of events: 2 exposures, 2 detections, 4 exposures potentially traced, 4 exposures actually traced, and 2 exams. The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 3.

variable-test.short-name: trace leads to previously detected unit
variable-test.description: Test that when a trace leads to a unit that has already been detected, an exam is not done.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Pig units ship to sheep units once per day. Sheep units ship to cattle units once per day. Latent units cannot be the source of an exposure. The probability of infection given exposure is always too low to infect.
Sheep and cattle units will be detected on the first day they show clinical signs. Pig units will be detected on the second day they show clinical signs. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. Unit 0 will be detected, the trace out will discover todays shipment to unit 1, and unit 1 will be examined (but there is no disease there to detect). Counts of events: 2 exposures, 1 detection, 1 exposure potentially traced, 1 exposure actually traced, and 1 exam. - On day 3 there will be no shipments because movement controls apply a day after the first detection. Unit 2 will be detected and the trace out will discover yesterdays shipment to unit 0. However, because unit 0 has already been detected, there will be no exam. Counts of events: 0 exposures, 1 detection, 1 exposure potentially traced, 1 exposure actually traced, and 0 exams. The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 3.

variable-test.short-name: exam and self-reporting on same day
variable-test.description: Test that when a unit can be detected by self-reporting and undergo an exam on the same day. (The two processes are allowed to be independent/concurrent.)
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Pig units ship to sheep units once per day. Sheep units ship to cattle units once per day. Latent units cannot be the source of an exposure. The probability of infection given exposure is always too low to infect.
For all production types, the probability of detection by self-reporting is too low on the first day the unit is showing clinical signs, but high enough to cause detection on the second day. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. No detections will happen. Counts of events: 2 exposures, 0 detections, 0 exposures potentially traced, 0 exposures actually traced, and 0 exams. - On day 2 unit 0 will again ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. Units 0 and 2 will be detected by self-reporting. The trace out from unit 2 will discover todays and yesterdays shipments to unit 0. An exam will detect disease at unit 0 and the trace out will continue to discover todays and yesterdays shipments to unit 1. An exam will not detect disease at unit 1. Counts of events: 2 exposures, 2 detections, 4 exposures potentially traced, 4 exposures actually traced, and 2 exams.\n\n Note that this scenario could be envisioned as playing out two ways. One possibility is that the detection of unit 0 by self-reporting happens first, and so there is no need for an exam when unit 0 is found by tracing from unit 2. The other possibility is that unit 0 is found by tracing first, and so it does need an exam. The model does not try to resolve this: rather, detection by self-reporting and detection by exams are treated as happening independently/concurrently, and so the exam always happens.\n\n The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 3.

stochastic-variable-test.short-name: test result and self-reporting on same day
stochastic-variable-test.description: Test which means of detection is output when a positive test result for a unit is released the same day the unit is detected by self-reporting.

For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.

Pig units will be detected on the first day they show clinical signs. Sheep and cattle units will be detected on the second day they show clinical signs. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined. If no clinical signs are detected by the visual exam, a test will be ordered. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1, and test results take 1 day.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. Unit 2 will be detected, the trace out will discover todays shipment to unit 0, and unit 0 will be examined. Clinical signs will not be detected at unit 0 (the probability is too low) so a test will be ordered. Count of detections: 1, by clinical signs. - On day 3 unit 0 will be detected by clinical signs. Also on day 3, the test result (positive) will be available for unit 0. Count of detections: only 1, with a 50/50 chance of credit for the detection going to self-reporting or testing.\n\n The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 3.

stochastic-variable-test.short-name: test result and self-reporting on same day, check first detection
stochastic-variable-test.description: Test how first detection broken down by means of detection is output when a positive test result for a unit is released the same day the unit is detected by self-reporting.
stochastic-variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
stochastic-variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "test result and self-reporting on same day" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. Unit 2 will be detected. This is the first detection overall, the first detection in pigs, and the first detection by clinical signs.

 The trace out from unit 2 will discover todays shipment to unit 0, and unit 0 will be examined. Clinical signs will not be detected at unit 0 (the probability is too low) so a test will be ordered. - On day 3 unit 0 will be detected by clinical signs. This is the first detection in sheep. Also on day 3, the test result (positive) will be available for unit 0. There is a 50/50 chance of credit for the detection going to self-reporting or testing. If credit goes to testing, this will be the first detection by testing.

 The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 3.

variable-test.short-name: test result after self-reporting
variable-test.description: Test whether it counts as a detection when a positive test result for a unit is released the day after the unit is detected by self-reporting (it should not, but the true positive test result should still be recorded).
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Pig units ship to sheep units once per day. Sheep units ship to cattle units once per day. Latent units cannot be the source of an exposure. The probability of infection given exposure is always too low to infect.
Pig units will be detected on the first day they show clinical signs. Sheep and cattle units will be detected on the second day they show clinical signs. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined. If no clinical signs are detected by the visual exam, a test will be ordered. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1, and test results take 2 days.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. Unit 2 will be detected, the trace out will discover todays shipment to unit 0, and unit 0 will be examined. Clinical signs will not be detected at unit 0 (the probability is too low) so a test will be ordered. Count of detections: 1. - On day 3 unit 0 will be detected by clinical signs. Count of detections: 1. - On day 4, the test result (positive) will be available for unit 0. Count of detections: 0 (this is not a new detection). Count of test results: 1 true positive.\n\n The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 4.

variable-test.short-name: self-reporting after positive test result
variable-test.description: Test whether a detection can occur by self-reporting after a positive test result is already known (it should not).
variable-test.author: <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious subclinical period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Pig units ship to sheep units once per day. Sheep units ship to cattle units once per day. Latent units cannot be the source of an exposure. The probability of infection given exposure is always too low to infect.
Pig units will be detected on the first day they show clinical signs. Sheep and cattle units will be detected on the second day they show clinical signs. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined. If no clinical signs are detected by the visual exam, a test will be ordered. The test sensitivity and specificity are both 1, and test results are available immediately.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Subclinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. - On day 3 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 2 will be detected, the trace out will discover yesterdays shipment to unit 0, and unit 0 will be examined. Clinical signs will not be detected at unit 0 (the probability is too low) so a test will be ordered. The test will discover the disease. Count of detections: 2. - On day 4 the probability of detection by clinical signs at unit 0 will be high enough that detection could occur, but since that unit was already detected by a test yesterday, no new detection should be recorded.\n\n The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 4.

variable-test.short-name: self-reporting after negative test result
variable-test.description: Test whether a detection can occur by self-reporting after a (false) negative test result is already known (it should).
variable-test.author: <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious subclinical period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Pig units ship to sheep units once per day. Sheep units ship to cattle units once per day. Latent units cannot be the source of an exposure. The probability of infection given exposure is always too low to infect.
Pig units will be detected on the first day they show clinical signs. Sheep and cattle units will be detected on the second day they show clinical signs. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1. On the day after the first detection, all direct contacts stop.
When a unit is detected, trace out (forward) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for finding recipient units. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined. If no clinical signs are detected by the visual exam, a test will be ordered. The test sensitivity is 0 and the specificity is 1. Test results are available immediately.
There is no vaccination or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 units 0 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Subclinical. 0 will ship to 1 and 2 will ship to 0. - On day 3 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 2 will be detected, the trace out will discover yesterdays shipment to unit 0, and unit 0 will be examined. Clinical signs will not be detected at unit 0 (the probability is too low) so a test will be ordered. The test will fail to discover the disease. Count of detections: 1. - On day 4 the probability of detection by clinical signs at unit 0 will be high enough that detection can occur. Unit 0 will be detected. Count of detections: 1.\n\n The scenario is deliberately stopped at day 4.

variable-test.short-name: trace back/in, count exams
variable-test.description: Create a situation where trace back/in from a detected unit causes an exam to be done on an as-yet-undetected unit.
variable-test.author: Deborah Batista <deborah.batista@colostate.edu>
Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For cattle, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious subclinical period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Cattle units ship to pig units once per day.
Pig units will be detected on the first day they show clinical signs. The probability of
When a unit is detected, that unit will be slated for destruction, and trace out (forward) and in (back) will be initiated. The probability of success for a trace investigation is 1, and there is no delay for conducting the trace. Units found by trace are quarantined and visually examined.
What should happen: - On day 1 both units will be Latent. The cattle unit will ship to the pig unit. - On day 2 the pig unit will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and trace in and out will be initiated. Trace in will find the cattle unit 0, and the cattle unit will be examined. However, the cattle unit is still Infectious Subclinical, so no signs of disease will be detected. - On day 3 the pig unit will be destroyed. The cattle unit will be Infectious Clinical, and it will be detected by clinical signs. - On day 4 the cattle unit will be destroyed.

variable-test.short-name: infections at day of first detection, 1 infection
variable-test.description: This is one of a set tests of the infections as of the day of first detection outputs. In this test, 1 infection has happened by the end of the day of first detection.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are adapted from the test prevalence increasing in the Airborne spread category of tests.
As the disease prevalence increases in the initially infected unit (unit 0), unit 1 gets an adequate exposure on day 4, unit 2 on day 5, and unit 3 on day 6.
Detection is set so that unit 0 will be detected on day 4, its first day showing clinical signs.
There is no vaccination or destruction in response to a detection.
What should happen: - Day 4 will be the day of first detection. - Up until day 4, the outputs firstDetUInfAll and firstDetAInfAll should have no numeric value. - On day 4, firstDetUInfAll should be 1 and firstDetAInfAll should be 25. (By the end of the day of first detection, 1 infection has occurred and the infected unit contains 25 animals.) - The test is deliberately stopped at 7 days.

variable-test.short-name: infections at day of first detection, 2 infections
variable-test.description: This is one of a set tests of the infections as of the day of first detection outputs. In this test, 2 infections have happened by the end of the day of first detection.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to the test infections at day of first detection, 1 infection above, expect this time detection is set so that unit 0 will be detected on day 5, its second day showing clinical signs.
What should happen: - Day 5 will be the day of first detection. - Up until day 5, the outputs firstDetUInfAll and firstDetAInfAll should have no numeric value. - On day 5, firstDetUInfAll should be 2 and firstDetAInfAll should be 50. (By the end of the day of first detection, 2 infections have occurred and the infected units contains 50 animals in total.) - The test is deliberately stopped at 7 days.

variable-test.short-name: infections at day of first detection, no detection
variable-test.description: This is one of a set tests of the infections as of the day of first detection outputs. In this test, there is no first detection.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to the test infections at day of first detection, 1 infection above, expect this time detection is set so that unit 0 will be detected on its fourth day showing clinical signs (which never happens, because the clinical period is only 3 days).
What should happen: - There will be no first detection, so the outputs firstDetUInfAll and firstDetAInfAll should never have a numeric value. - The test is deliberately stopped at 7 days.
